author: sky.cactus
content: You are running into the Singularity problem.  As the singularity approaches, the time between new tech showing up and tech becoming obsolete shrinks.  I actually have this same problem in a number of different industries right now.

author: sky.cactus
content: For example, I want to get into Controlled Environment Agriculture, but I also know that yeast/vat grown food is right around the corner and will potentially drive traditional agriculture out of business.

author: sky.cactus
content: Same with construction (advances in large scale 3D printing and materials science obsoletes stuff extremely fast).

author: sky.cactus
content: Also starting to show up in medicine.  There are gene therapies available today that you can get to increase your fitness (evolutionary use of the term), but they are quite expensive.  Chance are good that in a few years the cost of them will be a fraction of what they are today, so it is hard to judge when the "right" time to get them is.  Also with eye care, I could get LASIK today to fix my decaying vision, but I know that we are a short number of years away from far more advanced rejuvenation techniques (already tested in animal models).

author: tombrandstarkware
content:
I think this statement is incorrect -
There's already dYdX's ZK-rollup running today on Mainnet. I would argue the complexity of their application is at least on par with Augur/Maker. Furthermore, StarkNet Alpha is coming out to the public early next month (June) - it will allow anyone to write StarkNet contracts, which are very similar to Solidity contracts, deploy and run them (send transactions). The execution of those transactions will be proven and verified on L1.

author: .vbuterin
content: The Graph does not guarantee consensus on data availability

author: .vbuterin
content: You need a very specific property for the layer that you publish L2 data to, and it's stronger than just "you can usually fetch it"

author: .vbuterin
content: It's "you can _definitely_ fetch it, and even attackers publishing data have no way to generate an edge case where the data appears fetchable but is then unfetchable"

author: .vbuterin
content: And also "you can definitely determine that you know ALL the data that was successfully published that meets some criteria"

author: .vbuterin
content: Blockchains meet these properties, simple decentralized storage platforms do not
